It should be noted that although the overall response rate has fallen over the three surveys, the proportion of firms providing fee information has declined only marginally. At the time of the initial survey, the legal profession was highly sensitised to changes in practice rules governing advertising and to the impending entry of licensed conveyancers. The reduction in partial co-operators may be a reflection of the waning of interest and perhaps increased workloads.

More detailed analyses of the results for specific years and on specific topics are available in Love, Stephen, Gillanders and Paterson ( 1991 and 1992), McGough, O' Brien, Love and Stephen ( 1993), Stephen, Love, Paterson and Farmer (1989), Stephen, Love, Gillanders and Paterson (1992 and 1993) and Stephen, Love and Paterson (1994).

Logit regressions were used to test for a relationship between advertising and firm size in a multivariate context. Whilst this did reveal such a relationship in 1989, no such relationship was found in the other two years.
The register of the Council for Licensed Conveyancers showed 30, but we subsequently discovered that one was no longer in practice at the time of our survey.

In the course of interviews with solicitors, a few respondents suggested that they might opt for licensed conveyancer status because this would free them from Law Society rules which restricted their ability to 'compete' for business.

This observation is confirmed in a series of regressions to estimate the determinants of fees reported in Love, Stephen, Gillanders and Paterson ( 1991 and 1992), McGough, O'Brien, Love and Stephen (1993), Stephen, Love, Paterson and Farmer (1989), Stephen, Love, Gillanders and Paterson (1993) and Stephen, Love and Paterson (1994).

It should be noted that the period 1989-92 represents one of decline in the housing market throughout England and Wales. During this period, the Nationwide Building Society's index of house prices fell from 233.8 to 190.6.
Since we have information on only two fees, we cannot say that these solicitors charged the same fee for all transactions.

Stephen, Love, Gillanders and Paterson (1992 and 1993) analyse price discrimination in our sample markets in 1989. They find that the probability of a firm of solicitors being a price discriminator is significantly reduced the higher are the levels of certain advertising variables and the number of licensed conveyancers relative to the number of solicitors in the TTWA.
See Love, Stephen, Gillanders and Paterson (1992), McGough. O'Brien. Love and Stephen (1993), Stephen, Love, Paterson and Farmer ( 1989) and Stephen, Love and Paterson ( 1994).
